bibl.title: Letter from Joseph H. White to [Frederick F.] Russell, August 17, 1922

div1.p: White discusses ongoing mosquito eradication work in Mexico and South America.

div1.head: Letter from Joseph H. White to [Frederick F.] Russell, August 17, 1922
div1.opener:
C O P Y
Mexico,August 17, 1922.
Dear Russell:
div1.p:
Dr. Rose tells me he will be away until the end of September
and has left you to carry on at 61, so you are going to listen to the
story of Panuco.

For administrative purposes I am accepting the diagnosis of
Stubbs, confirmed by Perrin after examination of specimens of liver,
kidney and spleen, but I asked Perrin to send Noguchi a section of each
and wonder if he did.

I have put on a force to eliminate all Stegomyia in Panuco
and also all Anopheles since these latter, breeding in a pond in center
of town, are confusing diagnosis heavily.

My own private opinion remains unchanged and will so remain
until Noguchi says those tissues (not those I sent) from Prebyl's body
represent actual yellow fever.
Will you not see him and if you see fit show him this letter?

Prebyl and his chum, Richard Arthur, got sick about July 22
in Panuco. The former died on the 28th in Tampico - the latter 25th I
think in this city, and I am seeking his history. If both had yellow
fever then they were ex-mc-secondary cases and represent previous infection.

Both practically lived in the restricted district and, along
with dozens of other Americans of the so-called rough neck class, they
mingled freely night and day with the loose women. There are about 100
to 150 of each sex and all non-immune, and an incidence of 55% of house
infection with Stegs.

I know that it must spread under such conditions and altho
from 22nd to date 17th gives us 26 days and all we need minimally is
3 plus 12 plus 4 equal 19 days to show up fresh cases, there has not a
case shown up.

We have refrained from molesting the adult mosquito because
we wanted to know, and because I had faith in Connor to believe him when
he declared Tampico clean and I reviewed it and found an index down to 5%
and it has been three months.
Now, where did it come from if it is yellow fever?

I should like these facts submitted to Carter for an opinion,
because if it be true that yellow fever can lurk 18 months in the rural
districts or even 6 months, we must revise our whole scheme. I don't
2
believe it, and if Noguchi verifies Perrin's findings, I am then convinced
that Cuba or some other point within incubation period by ship from Panuco
is again lit up.

We are finding A.E. and Tertian in practically all blood
examined and the symptoms are well described (Connor says) in Chalmers
and Castellani on Tropical Diseases, pp. 1164-1172.

For my own part, after spending some days in Panuco, and
seeing cases and making an autopsy on a soldier who in life did look
suspicious and who died with uramic convulsions, I am satisfied that
I saw only malaria. I sent liver, spleen and kidney tissues on the
Mexico to Noguchi from that case, which was one of the sort most
frequently called yellow fever in this country.

As soon as this scare is over I am going to New York,
probably about October 1, and while there I want to talk to you and
Noguchi about the (in my opinion) necessity for a better study of
tropical malaria which is as different from home as it may well be,-
also other matters, so if you contemplate a hasty exit, write me and
let me adjust my plans.

closer.seg: P.S. Thanks for attention to L/C
